posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
Over the past few months I’ve been working on a side project that I thought some of you might find useful:

a web app for managing your team’s Bill of Materials and manufacturing workflow.

The idea came from the recurring headache of trying to track what parts were in CAD, what was COTS , what still needed to be made, and which machine it belonged on. Spreadsheets worked for a while, but they quickly became difficult to maintain once multiple people started editing at the same time.

I shared an early version of this site a while back, but since then it has improved significantly. The new version is far more polished — dashboards are clearer, Onshape integration is more reliable, and new features like live collaborative updates, system and robot statistics, and the 3D viewer make it genuinely practical to use during build season. What started as a proof of concept now feels like a tool teams can actually depend on.

Connect directly to Onshape (assemblies and part studios).

Automatically generate a BOM with fields like Part Name, Revision, Quantity, Material, CAD links, and custom process stages (Pre-process, Process 1, Process 2).

Filter by machine or stage (CNC, Lathe, 3D printer, etc.) with clear status indicators.

Collaborate live — updates to part quantities or statuses appear instantly for everyone.

Use dashboards for each system and the entire robot, with detailed completion statistics.

Preview 3D models directly in the browser without opening CAD.

Download CAD files for parts as needed.

If you’d like to explore the site, you can click the “Try a Demo” button at FRCBOM.com .

Full instructions are available here:

You can now re-import a BOM as many times as you need — if manufacturing has already started, the site remembers which parts were completed.

The user interface has been completely redesigned and is much more intuitive.

Each team gets its own automatically generated custom FeatureScript.

On the backend, the old single JSON file has been replaced with a proper database for speed, reliability, and scalability.

We already used it for our offseason project, building a 2022 robot and here are some pictures from the bom:

image 2529×1187 202 KB Works on tablets/phones too: image 760×1021 77.4 KB

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: This really is the BOM . com!

posts.name: Preston Childress
posts.cooked:
This is really cool!

It would be nice if there was a way to export DXFs of parts instead of just 3D formats - we use DXF for laser, waterjet, and plasma cutting.

posts.name: Andrew W
posts.cooked: We were just talking about wanting something similar the other day. This thing looks really cool!

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: I completely agree - we have a laser cutter too! But right now your export pipeline works well for STL and GLTF since Onshape’s API exposes those formats cleanly, but DXF export is much trickier to integrate for a laser cutter. The main challenge is that Onshape doesn’t inherently know which planar face of a 3D part should be flattened into a DXF — you either need a convention like “always take the largest planar face,” a custom property in Onshape that stores the target face ID, or a manual face selection in the UI before exporting. I will definitely look into it!

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: Very cool! Minor gripe, doesn’t look like I can update the thumbnail for a robot after I make it.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: There are still a few minor bugs in the system, nothing critical, but I wanted to release the site to the community and this is one of the issues holding it back. Specifically, adding a picture as a robot’s thumbnail is still a little buggy at the moment. But all of the functionality of the BOM works great!
